â
'''klik''' is a system for [[software]] [[download]] and usage on GNU/[[Linux]].
+
'''klik''' was a system for [[software]] [[download]] and usage on GNU/[[Linux]].
==Technology==
==Technology==
â
klik does not "install" software in the traditional sense (i.e., it does not put files all over the place in the system). It uses one .cmg [[computer file|file]] per [[application software|application]]. Each one is self-contained: it includes all [[library (software)|libraries]] the application [[dependency (computer science)|depends]] on and that are not part of the base system. In this regard, it is similar to "[[application virtualization]]". One can ''klik'' a file even if they are not a [[superuser]], or they are using a [[live CD]].
+
klik did not "install" software in the traditional sense (i.e., it did not put files all over the place in the system). It used one .cmg [[computer file|file]] per [[application software|application]]. Each one is self-contained: it includes all [[library (software)|libraries]] the application [[dependency (computer science)|depends]] on and that are not part of the base system. In this regard, it is similar to "[[application virtualization]]". One can ''klik'' a file even if they are not a [[superuser]], or they are using a [[live CD]].
â
klik is integrated with web browsers on the user's computer. Users download and install software by typing a URL beginning with <code>klik://</code>. This downloads a klik "recipe" file, which is used to generate the .cmg file. In this way, one recipe can be used to supply packages to a wide variety of platforms.
+
klik integrated with web browsers on the user's computer. Users downloaded and installed software by typing a URL beginning with <code>klik://</code>. This downloaded a klik "recipe" file, which was used to generate the .cmg file. In this way, one recipe could be used to supply packages to a wide variety of platforms.
â
klik files are often simpler than compiling and installing an application, as no installation actually takes place. The .cmg file is a compressed image which is temporarily mounted to allow access to the program, but not having to extract the program or modify the underlying system. Currently only 8 klik programs can be run at once because of the limitation of mounting compressed images with the [[Linux kernel]], unless [[FUSE (Linux)|FUSE]] is used. The file is remounted each time the program is run, meaning the user can remove the program by simply deleting the .cmg file.
+
klik files were often simpler than compiling and installing an application, as no installation actually took place. The .cmg file is a compressed image which is temporarily mounted to allow access to the program, but not having to extract the program or modify the underlying system. Currently only 8 klik programs can be run at once because of the limitation of mounting compressed images with the [[Linux kernel]], unless [[FUSE (Linux)|FUSE]] is used. The file is remounted each time the program is run, meaning the user can remove the program by simply deleting the .cmg file.
